bug.short_desc: Error Messages createdby an annotation processor are not shown when inheriting from a generated class

long_desc.thetext:
Hello,
at http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/annotation/processing/Filer.html it is suggested to inherit from classes generated by annotation processors: "Instead of modifying a class directly, the class is designed so that either its superclass is generated by annotation processing or ..."
I tried that approach and regognized the following: Eclipse APT seems to "forget" any error messages, that are reported by an annotation processor, as soon as the user creates a subclass of a generated class.
To reproduce, I have created a very simple processor, the always creates an error message and a single class called GeneratedClass. At first, the error message is shown as expected (for annotated class called "ExampleAnnotatedClass"). As soon as a subclass of GeneratedClass is added , the error message disappears. With maven , the error message is shown in both cases.
Steps to reproduce:
1.) unzip attachement 2.) for project eclipse-bug-processor, call "mvn install" to create the processor 3.) import project "eclipse-bug-test" as maven project into eclipse 4.) Either install the m2e-apt connector as suggested. (if not done before) Make sure, the m2e-option "Automatically configure JDT APT is selected" 5.) There is no APT error reported! 6.) Delete the class test.InheritedClass which extends GeneratedClass 7.) Clean / build the project 8.) Now, the error "Some Error Message" appears for ExampleAnnotatedClass.
(Note: I just use m2e-apt for easier configuration of the project. The bug also is there without maven... I have also attached the jar of the annotation processor. So, you don't have to use maven at all to reproduce.)
Created attachment 236620 Processor and example project to reproduce the bug
Created attachment 236621 The annotation processor JAR file

I can reproduce, it seems to me at some point, we throw away the CompilationResult and the errors reported on them and build a new one. Needs closer inspection, but could be a difficult one requiring changes at a basic level.

As part of fix to bug 269934, we made a decision to start over the compilation (even the already compiled ones, in this case, the ill-fated ExampleAnnotatedClass) when a previously-referenced-but-missing type is generated by the annotation processor. Unfortunately, we only know which types were missing (before they were created by the APT) but no way of knowing who needs it and needs to be rebuilt.
For other scenarios, we can look for units with reported problems and only recompile them, but alas, in our case, we are actually interested in seeing the previously reported error!
Stephan, I don't mean to hog your time, but if you find some time and have some thoughts, let me know. Otherwise, feel free to pass it.

At a high level, I can think of two possible ways to handle this:
1. Somehow remember which units that were affected by the missing type binding (only when dealing with annotation processing) and re-process only those units in case the missing type is generated by annotation processing.
2. When processing the units all over gain don't create new CompilationResult, but use the existing ones and preserve the errors/tasks not added by the compiler while re-compiling.
I see both have costs associated. But we might also find some benefits by not compiling all the units in the batch all over again.

(In reply to Jay Arthanareeswaran from comment #5) > At a high level, I can think of two possible ways to handle this:
Or when a source collision happens, go over the compiled units, make a copy of the APT problems and after re-compiling the batch again, inject the APT problems in appropriate units again?

(In reply to Jay Arthanareeswaran from comment #6) > (In reply to Jay Arthanareeswaran from comment #5) > > At a high level, I can think of two possible ways to handle this: > > Or when a source collision happens, go over the compiled units, make a copy > of the APT problems and after re-compiling the batch again, inject the APT > problems in appropriate units again?
This appears to be the simplest and least intrusive. I'll give it a shot.

Created attachment 252371 Propsed solution
This follows the third approach I mentioned earlier. Sounds more like a hack, but this is the least (if not non) intrusive as far as the compiler is concerned. Couple of concerns, this relies on that fact that APT problems are categorized as CategorizedProblem#CAT_UNSPECIFIED. Ideally we want another category here, but this is all API (too late for Mars) and too many clients might need to be updated. We will revisit this if we find a need, though.
Tests are being run.

(In reply to Jay Arthanareeswaran from comment #9) > Fix released via: > > http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/ > ?id=dec6a2f0da20e1df11b1bec260506ef56476e2e8
This is fix is causing a problem as reported in bug 463097, comment #9.
*** Bug 463097 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Will this fix work for other extensions of compilationParticipant?
Verified for 45 M7 using I20150429-2000 build

attachment.desc: Processor and example project to reproduce the bug
